<ce:section-title id="sect0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0045" view="all">The reaction of Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>tdc) and 1,2-bis(imidazol-1′-yl)methane (bimm) by modulating solvent systems yielded three highly connected pseudo-polymorphic coordination polymers based on different dinuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunits bridged by carboxylate groups. Single crystal structural analyses reveal structural variation from 4-connected 2D <ce:bold>sql</ce:bold> layer, 6-connected 2-fold interpenetrated 3D <ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> to 8-connected 3D <ce:bold>bcu</ce:bold>-type network in compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The structural dissimilarity in the structures dependent on the coordination environments of Cd(II) ions and linking modes of mixed ligand influenced by different solvent systems during the synthesis process. Moreover, thermogravimetric and photoluminescence behaviors of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were also investigated for the first time, and all the complexes emit blue luminescence in the solid state.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The reaction of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O, 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (H2tdc) and 1,2-bis(imidazol-1'-yl)methane (bimm) by modulating solvent systems yielded three highly connected pseudo-polymorphic coordination polymers based on different dinuclear [Cd2(CO2)2] subunits bridged by carboxylate groups. Single crystal structural analyses reveal structural variation from 4-connected 2D sql layer, 6-connected 2-fold interpenetrated 3D pcu to 8-connected 3D bcu-type network in compounds 1-3. The structural dissimilarity in the structures dependent on the coordination environments of Cd(II) ions and linking modes of mixed ligand influenced by different solvent systems during the synthesis process. Moreover, thermogravimetric and photoluminescence behaviors of 1-3 were also investigated for the first time, and all the complexes emit blue luminescence in the solid state.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Three solvent-dependent Cd(II) pseudo-polymorphic coordination polymers have been synthesized.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Structural variation from 4-connected 2D layer, 6-connected 2-fold interpenetrated 3D net to 8-connected 3D net.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">All complexes emit blue luminescence.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sect0025">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Recently, systematic efforts in coordination polymers (CPs) have been initiated toward the design and assembly of high-connectivity network structures for their potential advantages such as enhancing the network thermal stability, and having permanent porosity . However, the construction of highly-connected architectures remains a long-term challenge at this stage owing to the sterically demanding of organic ligands and the limited coordination numbers of metal centers . Thus, much effort has been devoted to selecting suitable organic building blocks to control the assembled motifs for building highly-connected architectures . Additionally, pseudo-polymorphic CPs, the existence of identical network architectures that contain different counterions, solvents, or guest molecules have received considerable attention in the field of crystal engineering . However, due to lower formation energy differences between pseudo-polymorphic CPs, the rational realization of a pseudo-polymorphic system is still difficult. According to the reported, many subtle environmental factors such as solvent molecules, pH value, additive agent, speed of crystallization, concentration effect as well as the stereochemistry of organic ligands and the temperature can affect the formation of pseudo-polymorphic system . Among them, solvent molecules have a significant effect by influencing coordination geometries of central metal ions and linking modes of organic ligands. To date, many elegant solvent-induced cases with topology changes have been reported , which are further encouraging us to exploit new pseudo-polymorphic CPs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Three solvent-dependent Cd(II) pseudo-polymorphic coordination polymers have been synthesized.

Structural variation from 4-connected 2D layer, 6-connected 2-fold interpenetrated 3D net to 8-connected 3D net.

All complexes emit blue luminescence.

Introduction

Recently, systematic efforts in coordination polymers (CPs) have been initiated toward the design and assembly of high-connectivity network structures for their potential advantages such as enhancing the network thermal stability, and having permanent porosity . However, the construction of highly-connected architectures remains a long-term challenge at this stage owing to the sterically demanding of organic ligands and the limited coordination numbers of metal centers . Thus, much effort has been devoted to selecting suitable organic building blocks to control the assembled motifs for building highly-connected architectures . Additionally, pseudo-polymorphic CPs, the existence of identical network architectures that contain different counterions, solvents, or guest molecules have received considerable attention in the field of crystal engineering . However, due to lower formation energy differences between pseudo-polymorphic CPs, the rational realization of a pseudo-polymorphic system is still difficult. According to the reported, many subtle environmental factors such as solvent molecules, pH value, additive agent, speed of crystallization, concentration effect as well as the stereochemistry of organic ligands and the temperature can affect the formation of pseudo-polymorphic system . Among them, solvent molecules have a significant effect by influencing coordination geometries of central metal ions and linking modes of organic ligands. To date, many elegant solvent-induced cases with topology changes have been reported , which are further encouraging us to exploit new pseudo-polymorphic CPs.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">In the assembly processes of CPs, flexible bis(imidazolyl) ligands have been employed to construct CPs because the ligands have strong coordination ability to transition metal ions and may allow the ligands to freely bend and rotate. Apart from bis(imidazolyl) ligands and metal ions, the multicarboxylate ligands also have an important effect on the assembly process of neutral bis (imidazolyl) ligands with metal ions in order for charge balance. In recent years, significant progress has been achieved using the combinations of thiophene-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>tdc) with C2-like symmetry and flexible bis(imidazolyl) ligands as mixed ligand to construct CPs . In our previous study, four CPs based on H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>tdc and flexible bis(2-methyl imidazole) ligands have been synthesized, which provide some insights into central metal ions, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>tdc and ancillary bis(2-methyl imidazole) ligands coordination-driven self-assembly of diverse structures and topologies . Inspired by the above work, we speculated that the replacement of bis(2-methyl imidazole) ligands by shorter and flexible 1,2-bis(imidazol-1′-yl)methane may produce intriguing CPs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the assembly processes of CPs, flexible bis(imidazolyl) ligands have been employed to construct CPs because the ligands have strong coordination ability to transition metal ions and may allow the ligands to freely bend and rotate. Apart from bis(imidazolyl) ligands and metal ions, the multicarboxylate ligands also have an important effect on the assembly process of neutral bis (imidazolyl) ligands with metal ions in order for charge balance. In recent years, significant progress has been achieved using the combinations of thiophene-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2tdc) with C2-like symmetry and flexible bis(imidazolyl) ligands as mixed ligand to construct CPs . In our previous study, four CPs based on H2tdc and flexible bis(2-methyl imidazole) ligands have been synthesized, which provide some insights into central metal ions, H2tdc and ancillary bis(2-methyl imidazole) ligands coordination-driven self-assembly of diverse structures and topologies . Inspired by the above work, we speculated that the replacement of bis(2-methyl imidazole) ligands by shorter and flexible 1,2-bis(imidazol-1'-yl)methane may produce intriguing CPs.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">In this work, Cd(II) ions have been employed as central metal ions because its d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> configuration and softness permit a wide variety of geometries and diverse coordination numbers, which may allow one to build highly-connected architectures. Fortunately, three solvent-dependent pseudo-polymorphic Cd(II)-containing CPs were obtained by modulating solvent systems(Scheme 1). To the best of our knowledge, there are no reports on the pseudo-polymorphic Cd(II)-containing CPs constructed from H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>tdc and flexible N-donor co-ligands. Meanwhile, topological variations, thermogravimetric and photoluminescence behaviors were also studied.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this work, Cd(II) ions have been employed as central metal ions because its d10 configuration and softness permit a wide variety of geometries and diverse coordination numbers, which may allow one to build highly-connected architectures. Fortunately, three solvent-dependent pseudo-polymorphic Cd(II)-containing CPs were obtained by modulating solvent systems(Scheme 1). To the best of our knowledge, there are no reports on the pseudo-polymorphic Cd(II)-containing CPs constructed from H2tdc and flexible N-donor co-ligands. Meanwhile, topological variations, thermogravimetric and photoluminescence behaviors were also studied.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0030">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0035">Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The ligand bimm was synthesized according to the literature method . Other commercially available chemicals and solvents are of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. The IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a Nicolet Avatar-360 spectrometer in the range of 4000 to 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1. 1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra was measured with a Bruker AVANCE-400 NMR spectrometer. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Flash 2000 elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8-ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer with Cu K<ce:italic>α</ce:italic> radiation (λ=1.5418<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out on a SDTQ600 thermogravimetric analyzer. A platinum pan was used for heating the sample with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min under a N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere. elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and methods

The ligand bimm was synthesized according to the literature method . Other commercially available chemicals and solvents are of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. The IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a Nicolet Avatar-360 spectrometer in the range of 4000 to 400cm-1. 1H NMR spectra was measured with a Bruker AVANCE-400 NMR spectrometer. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Flash 2000 elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8-ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5418Å). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out on a SDTQ600 thermogravimetric analyzer. A platinum pan was used for heating the sample with a heating rate of 10°C/min under a N2 atmosphere. Fluorescence measurements were recorded with a Hitachi F4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer.

A mixture containing Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.062g, 0.2mmol), H2tdc (0.034g, 0.2mmol), bimm (0.029g, 0.2mmol) and H2O-C2H5OH mixed solvent (8mL, v/v: 1/1)was placed in a 25mL Teflonlined autoclave and heated to 120°C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Then it was allowed to cool to room temperature, and colourless crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in about 32% yield (based on Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O). Anal. <ce:section-title id="sect0055">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The crystal structure data of <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> were collected on Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo K<ce:italic>α</ce:italic> (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) radiation using an <ce:italic>ω</ce:italic> scan mode at 293<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 296<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>2–3</ce:bold>. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program . The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full- matrix least-squares on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using the SHELXL-97 program package . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms on water molecules were located from difference Fourier maps and were refined using riding model. Other hydrogen atoms were placed at the calculation positions. The diffraction data of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was treated by the SQUEEZE method, as implemented in PLATON, to remove diffuse electron density associated with these badly disordered solvent molecules . A summary of the crystallographic data and selected bond lengths/angles are listed in <ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>
 and . Topology information for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were obtained using TOPOS4.0 program package .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

The crystal structure data of 1-3 were collected on Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ=0.71073Å) radiation using an ω scan mode at 293K for 1 and 296K for 2-3. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program . The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full- matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXL-97 program package . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms on water molecules were located from difference Fourier maps and were refined using riding model. Other hydrogen atoms were placed at the calculation positions. The diffraction data of 2 was treated by the SQUEEZE method, as implemented in PLATON, to remove diffuse electron density associated with these badly disordered solvent molecules . A summary of the crystallographic data and selected bond lengths/angles are listed in   and . Topology information for 1-3 were obtained using TOPOS4.0 program package .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0060">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0065">Structure descriptions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2(1)/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> space group and there are one independent Cd(II) ion, one tdc ligand and one bimm ligand in the asymmetric unit. As depicted in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>
a, each Cd(II) ion adopts a seven-coordinated pentagonal-bipyramidal configuration featuring contributions by five carboxylate oxygen atoms from three carboxylate groups of three tdc ligands and with Cd–O bond distance varying from 2.325(6) to 2.677 (5) Å, and two nitrogen atoms from bimm ligands with Cd–N bond lengths of 2.333(8) and 2.341(7) Å, respectively. In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, each tdc ligand adopts a (<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>−κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>−<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)−(<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)−<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> coordination fashion and connects three Cd(II) ions to produce a 1D chain containing dinuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunits with an edge-sharing polyhedron along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis (b). The Cd⋯Cd distance and O–Cd–O angle within the [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunits are 3.9216 (3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 80.801(2)°, respectively. In the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane, such chains are further sustained by bimm ligands to generate a dense 2D sheet, which are regarded as a simple 4-connected sql layer by simplifying the tdc and bimm ligands as linear connectors, binuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunits as a 4-connecting node (c and d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Structure descriptions

Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic P2(1)/c space group and there are one independent Cd(II) ion, one tdc ligand and one bimm ligand in the asymmetric unit. As depicted in  a, each Cd(II) ion adopts a seven-coordinated pentagonal-bipyramidal configuration featuring contributions by five carboxylate oxygen atoms from three carboxylate groups of three tdc ligands and with Cd-O bond distance varying from 2.325(6) to 2.677 (5) Å, and two nitrogen atoms from bimm ligands with Cd-N bond lengths of 2.333(8) and 2.341(7) Å, respectively. In 1, each tdc ligand adopts a (κ 2 -κ 1-μ 2)-(κ 2)-μ 3 coordination fashion and connects three Cd(II) ions to produce a 1D chain containing dinuclear [Cd2(CO2)2] subunits with an edge-sharing polyhedron along the a axis (b). The Cd⋯Cd distance and O-Cd-O angle within the [Cd2(CO2)2] subunits are 3.9216 (3)Å and 80.801(2)°, respectively. In the ab plane, such chains are further sustained by bimm ligands to generate a dense 2D sheet, which are regarded as a simple 4-connected sql layer by simplifying the tdc and bimm ligands as linear connectors, binuclear [Cd2(CO2)2] subunits as a 4-connecting node (c and d).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">When changing H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O–C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH solvent to H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in the reaction system, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is obtained. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> also crystallizes in the monoclinic <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2(1)/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> space group and has a unique 3D→3D two-fold interpenetrating motif. There are two Cd(II) ions, two bimm ligands, two tdc ligands together with four lattice water molecules in the asymmetric unit (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>
a). The two crystallographically independent centers, Cd1 and Cd2, reside in similar coordination environments and are coordinated with four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three tdc ligands, and two nitrogen atoms from two bimm ligands, showing the distorted octahedral coordination geometry. As shown in (b), each deprotonated tdc ligand exhibits the (<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>−<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>−<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)−(<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)−<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> binding fashion to connect three Cd(II) ions to generate a 2D layer structure containing a similar [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunit. The Cd⋯Cd distance and O–Cd–O angle within the [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] core are 3.7794 (3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 76.253(78)°, respectively. These dinuclear units are further connected to their subsequent neighbors through bimm ligands and generate a 3D framework (c). From the topological point of view, the structure of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be represented as a uninodal 6-connected <ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> network with a Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>0.6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> (d) . The 3D <ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> framework possesses large channels which allow further nucleation in the void space to generate a 2-fold interpenetrated structure, and thus reducing the void volume completely. PLATON calculations indicate that the effective volume is 515.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> per unit cell, which is 15.8% of the crystal volume.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: When changing H2O-C2H5OH solvent to H2O in the reaction system, 2 is obtained. Compound 2 also crystallizes in the monoclinic P2(1)/c space group and has a unique 3D→3D two-fold interpenetrating motif. There are two Cd(II) ions, two bimm ligands, two tdc ligands together with four lattice water molecules in the asymmetric unit ( a). The two crystallographically independent centers, Cd1 and Cd2, reside in similar coordination environments and are coordinated with four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three tdc ligands, and two nitrogen atoms from two bimm ligands, showing the distorted octahedral coordination geometry. As shown in (b), each deprotonated tdc ligand exhibits the (κ 1-κ 1-μ 2)-(κ 2)-μ 3 binding fashion to connect three Cd(II) ions to generate a 2D layer structure containing a similar [Cd2(CO2)2] subunit. The Cd⋯Cd distance and O-Cd-O angle within the [Cd2(CO2)2] core are 3.7794 (3)Å and 76.253(78)°, respectively. These dinuclear units are further connected to their subsequent neighbors through bimm ligands and generate a 3D framework (c). From the topological point of view, the structure of complex 2 can be represented as a uninodal 6-connected pcu network with a Schläfli symbol of 4120.63 (d) . The 3D pcu framework possesses large channels which allow further nucleation in the void space to generate a 2-fold interpenetrated structure, and thus reducing the void volume completely. PLATON calculations indicate that the effective volume is 515.7Å3 per unit cell, which is 15.8% of the crystal volume.

<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">When replacing H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O with DMF solven, we obtained <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> as 8-connected 3D network with 1D open channels. Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group <ce:italic>Pbca</ce:italic>. The asymmetric unit consists of one Cd(II) ion, one bimm ligand, one tdc ligand together with one uncoordinated DMF molecule. As shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>
a, the coordination environment around 6-coordinated Cd(II) ion can be described as a distorted octahedral geometry, being coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms of tdc ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two bimm ligands. The bond lengths of Cd–N are 2.309(3) (Cd–N2) and 2.278(3) Å (Cd–N5), while the Cd–O bond lengths vary from 2.225(2) to 2.609(3) Å, which are in the normal range. In <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, each tdc ligand adopts a (<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>−<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>−<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)−(<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)<ce:italic>−μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> bridging fashion and connects three Cd(II) ions to produce a 2D layer structure with a [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunit with an edge-sharing polyhedron along the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane (b). The Cd⋯Cd distance and O–Cd–O angle within the [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunits are 3.7652 (5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 76.457(82)°, respectively. The subunits are further connected to their subsequent neighbors through bimm ligands infinitely creating a 3D framework having small continuous 8.31×8.22<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å channels along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> direction to which DMF guest molecules point (taking into account the van der Waals radii of the atoms) (c). The total potential solvent-accessible volumes of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are calculated to be 29.6% (1174.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> out of 3968.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> per unit cell volume) after squeezing DMF molecules by PLATON program. From a topological viewpoint, each [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] core can be considered as a 8- connected node which links with eight neighboring [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunits. Based on this simplication, the overall 3D network of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be rationalized as a 8-connected body-centered cubic (<ce:bold>bcu</ce:bold>) topology with a Schläfli symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">24</ce:sup>0.6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>) (d) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: When replacing H2O with DMF solven, we obtained 3 as 8-connected 3D network with 1D open channels. Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 3 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca. The asymmetric unit consists of one Cd(II) ion, one bimm ligand, one tdc ligand together with one uncoordinated DMF molecule. As shown in  a, the coordination environment around 6-coordinated Cd(II) ion can be described as a distorted octahedral geometry, being coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms of tdc ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two bimm ligands. The bond lengths of Cd-N are 2.309(3) (Cd-N2) and 2.278(3) Å (Cd-N5), while the Cd-O bond lengths vary from 2.225(2) to 2.609(3) Å, which are in the normal range. In 3, each tdc ligand adopts a (κ 1-κ 1-μ 2)-(κ 2)-μ 3 bridging fashion and connects three Cd(II) ions to produce a 2D layer structure with a [Cd2(CO2)2] subunit with an edge-sharing polyhedron along the ab plane (b). The Cd⋯Cd distance and O-Cd-O angle within the [Cd2(CO2)2] subunits are 3.7652 (5)Å and 76.457(82)°, respectively. The subunits are further connected to their subsequent neighbors through bimm ligands infinitely creating a 3D framework having small continuous 8.31×8.22Å channels along the a direction to which DMF guest molecules point (taking into account the van der Waals radii of the atoms) (c). The total potential solvent-accessible volumes of 3 are calculated to be 29.6% (1174.8Å3 out of 3968.7Å3 per unit cell volume) after squeezing DMF molecules by PLATON program. From a topological viewpoint, each [Cd2(CO2)2] core can be considered as a 8- connected node which links with eight neighboring [Cd2(CO2)2] subunits. Based on this simplication, the overall 3D network of 1 can be rationalized as a 8-connected body-centered cubic (bcu) topology with a Schläfli symbol of (4240.64) (d) .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0070">Synthesis and general characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">As described above, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have been obtained based on different reaction solvent systems, while the other synthetic parameters were intentionally held constant. The reaction in mixed solvent of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH affords the formation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Although no solvent molecules participated in the final crystalline products, the mixed solvent is critical to form the compound by the synergy effect between H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH molecules. No crystalline solid will be formed if the pure C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH is used, while <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> forms in pure H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O solvent. The reaction in the DMF solvent gives the resultant complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. At the same time, we also tried other solvents such as acetonitrile, methanol or mixture of them with water, but only some precipitates or microcrystalline products that are unsuitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and general characterization

As described above, 1-3 have been obtained based on different reaction solvent systems, while the other synthetic parameters were intentionally held constant. The reaction in mixed solvent of H2O and C2H5OH affords the formation of 1. Although no solvent molecules participated in the final crystalline products, the mixed solvent is critical to form the compound by the synergy effect between H2O and C2H5OH molecules. No crystalline solid will be formed if the pure C2H5OH is used, while 2 forms in pure H2O solvent. The reaction in the DMF solvent gives the resultant complex 3. At the same time, we also tried other solvents such as acetonitrile, methanol or mixture of them with water, but only some precipitates or microcrystalline products that are unsuitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The structural transformations are induced by the coordination environments of Cd(II) ion and linking modes of tdc and bimm ligands, which are clearly mediated by different solvent systems in the self-assembly process. In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, tdc ligands adopt (<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>−<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>−<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)−(<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)−<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or (<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>−<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>−<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)−(<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)−<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> bridging fashion to connect Cd(II) ions, respectively, giving three different dinuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunits, which were connected through flexible bimm ligands to generate 4-, 6- and 8t-connected CPs. The bimm ligands exhibit a relatively rotation, in which dihedral angles between two imidazole rings are 84.802° for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 83.457° and 66.921° for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 72.7619° for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively. In general, the pseudo-polymorphic compound mediated by the solvents is fortuitously observed. At present, although more theoretical analysis and experimental studies of solvent effect are required in controlling the final structures, some general rules and conclusions may be assumed. It is certainly possible that solvent system may influence the solvation process and coordination kinetics in solution.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structural transformations are induced by the coordination environments of Cd(II) ion and linking modes of tdc and bimm ligands, which are clearly mediated by different solvent systems in the self-assembly process. In 1-3, tdc ligands adopt (κ 2-κ 1-μ 2)-(κ 2)-μ 3 or (κ 1-κ 1-μ 2)-(κ 2)-μ 3 bridging fashion to connect Cd(II) ions, respectively, giving three different dinuclear [Cd2(CO2)2] subunits, which were connected through flexible bimm ligands to generate 4-, 6- and 8t-connected CPs. The bimm ligands exhibit a relatively rotation, in which dihedral angles between two imidazole rings are 84.802° for 1, 83.457° and 66.921° for 2, 72.7619° for 3, respectively. In general, the pseudo-polymorphic compound mediated by the solvents is fortuitously observed. At present, although more theoretical analysis and experimental studies of solvent effect are required in controlling the final structures, some general rules and conclusions may be assumed. It is certainly possible that solvent system may influence the solvation process and coordination kinetics in solution.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0085" view="all">At room temperature, complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are stable and not soluble in water and common organic solvents. The elemental analysis results match well with the composition of crystal structure determination. The phase purity is confirmed through powder X-ray diffraction technique, the experimental and simulated PXRD patterns are matched well for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>
). The dissimilarities in intensity could be owing to the preferred orientation of the crystalline powder samples.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: At room temperature, complexes 1-3 are stable and not soluble in water and common organic solvents. The elemental analysis results match well with the composition of crystal structure determination. The phase purity is confirmed through powder X-ray diffraction technique, the experimental and simulated PXRD patterns are matched well for 1-3, respectively ( ). The dissimilarities in intensity could be owing to the preferred orientation of the crystalline powder samples.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0075">Thermogravimetric analyses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">Thermal behaviors of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have been characterized by thermogravimetric analysis (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>
). No obvious weight loss was found for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> before the decomposition occurred at about 230<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which is in good agreement with the results of the crystal structure. For <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, a weight loss of 7.82% before 102<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C indicates the exclusion of four water molecules (calc. 7.71%), and the host framework can be stable up to 269<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. For <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, there is no significant weight loss before 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and then the gradual weight loss of 14.51% that takes place between 120 and 272<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C corresponds to the removal of uncoordinated DMF molecules (calcd: 14.49%). Above 272<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> begins to collapse of the framework, accompanied by the release of tdc and bimm ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric analyses

Thermal behaviors of 1-3 have been characterized by thermogravimetric analysis ( ). No obvious weight loss was found for 1 before the decomposition occurred at about 230°C, which is in good agreement with the results of the crystal structure. For 2, a weight loss of 7.82% before 102°C indicates the exclusion of four water molecules (calc. 7.71%), and the host framework can be stable up to 269°C. For 3, there is no significant weight loss before 120°C, and then the gradual weight loss of 14.51% that takes place between 120 and 272°C corresponds to the removal of uncoordinated DMF molecules (calcd: 14.49%). Above 272°C, 3 begins to collapse of the framework, accompanied by the release of tdc and bimm ligands.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0080">Luminescent properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">The luminescent properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> together with free organic ligands were studied in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>
, the emission spectra for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibit main emission peaks in the range of 350–600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm at 412<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, 407<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, and 416<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively. The free ligands display luminescence with emission at 354<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>=280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for bimm and 380<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>=300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>tdc, which may be ascribed to the π<ce:sup loc="post">*</ce:sup>→n or π<ce:sup loc="post">*</ce:sup>→π transitions . At present, it is still a challenge to illustrate the luminescence behaviors of the cooperatively CPs mixing two types of organic linkers. The emission band of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> could be tentatively attributed to both a combination of the charge transfer process and intraligand π*→n or π*→π transition originating from different chromophores in the crystal structures as reported for d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal compounds with N-donor ligands  (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>
.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent properties

The luminescent properties of 1-3 together with free organic ligands were studied in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in  , the emission spectra for 1-3 exhibit main emission peaks in the range of 350-600nm at 412nm, 407nm, and 416nm upon excitation at 300nm, respectively. The free ligands display luminescence with emission at 354nm (λex=280nm) for bimm and 380nm (λex=300nm) for H2tdc, which may be ascribed to the π*→n or π*→π transitions . At present, it is still a challenge to illustrate the luminescence behaviors of the cooperatively CPs mixing two types of organic linkers. The emission band of 1-3 could be tentatively attributed to both a combination of the charge transfer process and intraligand π*→n or π*→π transition originating from different chromophores in the crystal structures as reported for d10 metal compounds with N-donor ligands  ( .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0085">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0100" view="all">In summary, we have successfully constructed and characterized three highly connected supramolecular isomers containing dinuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] metal carboxylate cores. They showed high structural diversity depending on the solvent-dependent synthesis. The present work is important not only in generating new Cd(II) CPs with interesting structures but also in providing opportunities to understand the details in the crystallization process, and it will significantly enrich our knowledge of assembly processes of CPs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully constructed and characterized three highly connected supramolecular isomers containing dinuclear [Cd2(CO2)2] metal carboxylate cores. They showed high structural diversity depending on the solvent-dependent synthesis. The present work is important not only in generating new Cd(II) CPs with interesting structures but also in providing opportunities to understand the details in the crystallization process, and it will significantly enrich our knowledge of assembly processes of CPs.

cln_elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0040">Synthesis of Cd(tdc)(bimm)<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">A mixture containing Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.062<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>tdc (0.034<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), bimm (0.029<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O–C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH mixed solvent (8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL, v/v: 1/1)was placed in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflonlined autoclave and heated to 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Then it was allowed to cool to room temperature, and colourless crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in about 32% yield (based on Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O). Anal. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>SCd: C 36.22, H 2.32, N 13.00%. Found: C 35.87, H 2.39, N 12.91%. Colourless crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in about 19% yield (based on Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O). Synthesis of Cd(tdc)(bimm)n (1)

A mixture containing Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.062g, 0.2mmol), H2tdc (0.034g, 0.2mmol), bimm (0.029g, 0.2mmol) and H2O-C2H5OH mixed solvent (8mL, v/v: 1/1)was placed in a 25mL Teflonlined autoclave and heated to 120°C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Then it was allowed to cool to room temperature, and colourless crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in about 32% yield (based on Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O). Anal. Calc. for C13H10N4O4SCd: C 36.22, H 2.32, N 13.00%. Found: C 35.87, H 2.39, N 12.91%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3020w, 1625m, 1575s, 1530s, 1468w, 1421s, 1384m, 1348s, 1309m, 1236s, 1202w, 1080s, 1028m, 948m, 871m, 821s, 797m, 764s, 732s, 686m, 645m.

Synthesis of [Cd2(tdc)2(bimm)2](H2O)4 (2)

The synthesis of 2 was similar to that of 1, but using H2O (8mL) solvent instead of H2O-C2H5OH mixed solvent. Colourless crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in about 19% yield (based on Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O). Anal. Calc. for C13H14N4O6SCd: C 33.43, H 3.00, N 12.00%. Found: C 33.37, H 2.96, N 11.96%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3347w, 2363w, 1670m, 1588s, 1553s, 1489m, 1465m, 1429s, 1390s, 1341s, 1280w, 1222m, 1134w, 1055m, 1003m, 927m, 893m, 815s, 700s, 645m.

Synthesis of [Cd(tdc)(bimm)](DMF) (3)

Complex 3 was prepared in the same way as 2 except that DMF was used instead of H2O. Colourless crystals of 3 suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in about 56% yield (based on Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O). Anal. Calc. for C16H17N5O5SCd: C 38.11, H 3.37, N 13.89%. Found: C 38.09, H 3.40, N 13.76%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3071w, 2817w, 1675s, 1601w, 1582m, 1496m, 1453m, 1420m, 1323m, 1288s, 1186m, 1127m, 1072w, 1026m, 1001w, 932s, 805m, 703s, 683m, 666s

When changing H2O-C2H5OH solvent to H2O in the reaction system, 2 is obtained. Compound 2 also crystallizes in the monoclinic P2(1)/c space group and has a unique 3D→3D two-fold interpenetrating motif. There are two Cd(II) ions, two bimm ligands, two tdc ligands together with four lattice water molecules in the asymmetric unit ( a). The two crystallographically independent centers, Cd1 and Cd2, reside in similar coordination environments and are coordinated with four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three tdc ligands, and two nitrogen atoms from two bimm ligands, showing the distorted octahedral coordination geometry. As shown in (b), each deprotonated tdc ligand exhibits the (κ 1-κ 1-μ 2)-(κ 2)-μ 3 binding fashion to connect three Cd(II) ions to generate a 2D layer structure containing a similar [Cd2(CO2)2] subunit. The Cd⋯Cd distance and O-Cd-O angle within the [Cd2(CO2)2] core are 3.7794 (3)Å and 76.253(78)°, respectively. These dinuclear units are further connected to their subsequent neighbors through bimm ligands and generate a 3D framework (c). From the topological point of view, the structure of complex 2 can be represented as a uninodal 6-connected pcu network with a Schläfli symbol of 4120.63 (d) . The 3D pcu framework possesses large channels which allow further nucleation in the void space to generate a 2-fold interpenetrated structure, and thus reducing the void volume completely. PLATON calculations indicate that the effective volume is 515.7Å3 per unit cell, which is 15.8% of the crystal volume.

When replacing H2O with DMF solven, we obtained 3 as 8-connected 3D network with 1D open channels. Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 3 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca. The asymmetric unit consists of one Cd(II) ion, one bimm ligand, one tdc ligand together with one uncoordinated DMF molecule. As shown in  a, the coordination environment around 6-coordinated Cd(II) ion can be described as a distorted octahedral geometry, being coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms of tdc ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two bimm ligands. The bond lengths of Cd-N are 2.309(3) (Cd-N2) and 2.278(3) Å (Cd-N5), while the Cd-O bond lengths vary from 2.225(2) to 2.609(3) Å, which are in the normal range. In 3, each tdc ligand adopts a (κ 1-κ 1-μ 2)-(κ 2)-μ 3 bridging fashion and connects three Cd(II) ions to produce a 2D layer structure with a [Cd2(CO2)2] subunit with an edge-sharing polyhedron along the ab plane (b). The Cd⋯Cd distance and O-Cd-O angle within the [Cd2(CO2)2] subunits are 3.7652 (5)Å and 76.457(82)°, respectively. The subunits are further connected to their subsequent neighbors through bimm ligands infinitely creating a 3D framework having small continuous 8.31×8.22Å channels along the a direction to which DMF guest molecules point (taking into account the van der Waals radii of the atoms) (c). The total potential solvent-accessible volumes of 3 are calculated to be 29.6% (1174.8Å3 out of 3968.7Å3 per unit cell volume) after squeezing DMF molecules by PLATON program. From a topological viewpoint, each [Cd2(CO2)2] core can be considered as a 8- connected node which links with eight neighboring [Cd2(CO2)2] subunits. Based on this simplication, the overall 3D network of 1 can be rationalized as a 8-connected body-centered cubic (bcu) topology with a Schläfli symbol of (4240.64) (d) .

Thermogravimetric analyses

Thermal behaviors of 1-3 have been characterized by thermogravimetric analysis ( ). No obvious weight loss was found for 1 before the decomposition occurred at about 230°C, which is in good agreement with the results of the crystal structure. For 2, a weight loss of 7.82% before 102°C indicates the exclusion of four water molecules (calc. 7.71%), and the host framework can be stable up to 269°C. For 3, there is no significant weight loss before 120°C, and then the gradual weight loss of 14.51% that takes place between 120 and 272°C corresponds to the removal of uncoordinated DMF molecules (calcd: 14.49%). Above 272°C, 3 begins to collapse of the framework, accompanied by the release of tdc and bimm ligands.

Luminescent properties

The luminescent properties of 1-3 together with free organic ligands were studied in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in  , the emission spectra for 1-3 exhibit main emission peaks in the range of 350-600nm at 412nm, 407nm, and 416nm upon excitation at 300nm, respectively. The free ligands display luminescence with emission at 354nm (λex=280nm) for bimm and 380nm (λex=300nm) for H2tdc, which may be ascribed to the π*→n or π*→π transitions . At present, it is still a challenge to illustrate the luminescence behaviors of the cooperatively CPs mixing two types of organic linkers. The emission band of 1-3 could be tentatively attributed to both a combination of the charge transfer process and intraligand π*→n or π*→π transition originating from different chromophores in the crystal structures as reported for d10 metal compounds with N-donor ligands  ( .
